main event: A white, round object the size of a pea with a bright tail was observed for three consecutive nights in Lafayette, Indiana, in 1956. It remained stationary and then moved to the southwest.
interesting points: The object was observed for three consecutive nights, showing consistent behavior.
It was classified as a star/planet due to its characteristics, although positional data was not included in the report.
The report includes a civilian source and photographs of the object.
The document suggests that the object could have been a balloon, aircraft, or an astronomical body, but the conclusion was 'Unknown' due to insufficient data for evaluation.
There were measurements of visibility and weather conditions provided during the time of the sighting.
